awd_titl_txt: Geometry of manifolds with large volume
awd_abstract_narration:
A thin rubber sphere can be stretched, pushed in, and otherwise distorted so that its roundness is lost. For instance, one can contract the equator to transform the round sphere into an hourglass. While the neck of the hourglass does not look much like a round sphere anymore, the two bulbs are still pretty round. The celebrated Gauss-Bonnet theorem says that in some precise sense, no matter how the sphere is distorted, the average geometry of the result will still be round. Mathematicians view this result as an example where the topology of an object (i.e., the fact that it was produced by distorting a round sphere) constrains its geometry. The broad theme of this proposal is to develop similar results pertaining to higher dimensional abstract geometric objects. 

Thurston's Geometrization Conjecture, proved by Perelman in 2003, states that every closed three-manifold can be cut into pieces, each of which admits one of eight types of homogenous metrics. Of these pieces, only the hyperbolic three-manifolds have not been classified.  The full statement of the Perelman's result includes topological conditions that characterize when a closed three-manifold M admits a hyperbolic metric. Mostow's Rigidity Theorem implies that a hyperbolic metric on such an M is unique, if it exists, so it is natural to try to extract concrete geometric information about the metric from the topology of M. Effective geometrization, studied by the PI and his collaborators, is a program to extract concrete geometric information about a hyperbolic metric on a three-dimensional manifold from its topology. A large part of this project involves finding a description of the geometry of M given only that the number of elements needed to generate the fundamental group of M is bounded, or that M has a topological decomposition with certain characteristics. The key technique is to understand a sequence of closed hyperbolic three-manifolds asymptotically by passing to geometric limits. This perspective will also be applied outside of hyperbolic geometry, in the study of the growth of Betti numbers in sequences of higher rank locally symmetric spaces, in a program inspired by an active field in graph theory.

por.por_cntn:
The funded project had two main goals: to understand the geometric constraints on a closed hyperbolic 3-manifold imposed by the rank of its fundamental group, and to estimate the growth of Betti numbers of locally symmetric spaces. Part of the latter goal involved understanding unimodular measures on the space of all pointed Riemannian manifolds, in particular those supported on the set of quotients of a fixed symmetric space. In the locally symmetric setting, these measures can also be interpreted algebraically as invariant random subgroups of a Lie group G, which are conjugation invariant measures on the space of all closed subgroups of G. 

 

During the course of the grant, the PI finished a long paper with Souto on the geometry of thick hyperbolic 3-manifolds with bounded rank, showing that all such manifolds decompose into boundedly many bounded diameter "building blocks" glued together along "wide product regions". With Abert--Bergeron--Gelander, he showed that if X is any symmetric space of noncompact type other than H^3, then the sequence of volume-normalized Betti numbers associated to any sequence of finite volume quotients of X converges, as long as the sequence of quotients converges in the sense of Benjamini-Schramm. As a Corollary, when X has higher rank the volume-normalized Betti numbers of any such sequence converges to the L2-Betti numbers of X. With Lazarovich and Leitner, the PI has also begun a deep study of the global topology Sub(G) of the Chabauty space of all closed subgroups of G=PSL(2,R); their first paper on the subject recently appeared, and the goal of the project is to understand the fundamental group of Sub(G), among other things.

 

The broader impacts of the PI's work included: 

1) the development of his online book "Geometry in Two Dimensions", which gives undergraduate math majors a taste of modern geometry,

2) the improvement of his inquiry-based scripts for his Introduction to Proofs class, which are made available online on his website,

3) the training of three PhD students, and the mentoring of a postdoc, and multiple undergraduate research projects,

4) two summer workshops for early-career mathematicians.
